Cards.Back: A named storage location in memory that holds a value which can change during program execution
A step-by-step procedure or formula for solving a problem or accomplishing a task

Cards.Front: What are the three basic control structures in programming?
Cards.Back: Sequence (linear execution), Selection (if/else), and Iteration (loops)

Cards.Front: What is the difference between a while loop and a for loop?
Cards.Back: While loops repeat while a condition is true. For loops are typically used when the number of iterations is known
A reusable block of code that performs a specific task, can accept parameters and return a value

Cards.Front: What is the difference between parameters and arguments?
Cards.Back: Parameters are variables in the method definition, arguments are the actual values passed when calling the method
The region of code where a variable is accessible. Variables can have local, class, or global scope
A data structure that stores a fixed-size collection of elements of the same type in contiguous memory
The position of an element in an array. Most languages use zero-based indexing (first element is at index 0)
A data type that can only be true or false, used for logical operations and conditions
Operators that work with boolean values: AND (&&), OR (||), NOT (!)

Cards.Front: What is the difference between = and == ?
Cards.Back: = is assignment (assigns a value), == is comparison (checks if two values are equal)
Joining two or more strings together into one string
The process of finding and fixing errors (bugs) in code

Cards.Front: What is the difference between syntax errors and logic errors?
Cards.Back: Syntax errors violate language rules and prevent compilation. Logic errors compile but produce incorrect results
The process of repeating a set of instructions, typically using loops

Cards.Front: What does it mean to 'initialize' a variable?
Cards.Back: To declare a variable and assign it an initial value

Cards.Front: What is a comment in code?
Cards.Back: Text in code that is ignored by the compiler, used to explain code for human readers
A loop inside another loop, where the inner loop completes all iterations for each iteration of the outer loop
An operator that returns the remainder after division (e.g., 7 % 3 = 1)
